channel.title: #Rstats on Ken's Blog
channel.description: Recent content in #Rstats on Ken's Blog

item.title: A brief foray into list-columns
item.description: Introduction Let’s suppose we are trying to find the median of a bunch of binomial distributions. ⊕This is a simplified version of an actual problem I had, but that one fails for some unconnected (and thus far unknown) reason, so I don’t want to show you that. To be specific, let’s suppose we have these values of \(n\): n=c(10,15,20) and these values of \(p\): p=c(0.25,0.3,0.42) We’ll need the tidyverse, as usual:

item.title: Summarizing several models using broom and purrr
item.description: Introduction broom is supposed to be a powerful way to summarize several models at once, and so it is. The trouble is, the examples show how to fit the same model to different subsets of a data set. I had something different in mind: I had one data set, and three different models on that same data. Could I do something similar there? It wasn’t clear to me how. Illustrative data The data here came from Albright’s book.
